item.title: Remembering the Nevada Palace: A Brief, Turbulent History on Boulder Highway
item.description:
From Dream to Demolition: The Nevada Palace’s Story

The Nevada Palace Hotel and Casino. The name might not immediately ring a bell for many modern Vegas visitors, but for those who remember the early 1980s, it represents a short, sharp, and ultimately tragic chapter in Las Vegas’s ever-evolving story. Opened on July 3, 1979, along Boulder Highway, the Palace was a venture spearheaded by casino veteran Gene Lucas, along with Robert Mariscal, Bill Gallagher, Dan Straub, and Rene Diaz. They envisioned a mid-tier property aiming for a friendly, approachable vibe – a contrast to the increasingly opulent and high-roller-focused Strip. Initially boasting just 100 hotel rooms and 15,000 square feet of casino space, it offered a modest, yet seemingly viable, gaming experience.
